Guide to the siricid woodwasps of North America
Nathan M. Schiff Schiff, Nathan M. United States Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Southern Research Station, Center for Bottomland Hardwoods Research , 200 W.T. Weaver Blvd. Asheville, NC 28804-3454
author
Steven A. Valley Valley, Steven A.
author
James R. LaBonte LaBonte, James R.
author
David R. Smith Smith, David R. United States Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Forest Products Laboratory, , One Gifford Pinchot Drive, Madison, WI 53726
author
SRStext article
2008-01-07
Informally Refereed (Peer-Reviewed)
eng English
The Siricidae are a family of large, colorful, stingless wasps whose larvae bore into wood. They are members of the suborder Symphyta (sawflies, and horntails or woodwasps) of the insect order Hymenoptera (ants, wasps, and bees), and are characterized by having a broad waist and an ovipositor modified to insert eggs into wood.
Forest Service, Forest Health Technology Enterprise Team
